Course Description: The course will provide a theoretical understanding of behavioural economics, and then apply these theories to do experimental analysis in a laboratory setting. Behavioural economics incorporates human traits of cognition, social preferences, and emotional responses to better understand choices made in a setting that may not seem 'rational' in the traditional sense of the word. Understanding of choices influenced by behaviour is useful in a variety of arenas, including policy making, IO, and finance. Behavioural economics literature also has inter-disciplinary relevance with psychology and cognitive sciences.

Course Outcomes.CO1: Identify how individuals influenced by behavioural biases behave differently from perfectly rational agents
Course Outcomes.CO2: Explaining the relevance of risk, uncertainty and time in individual decisions.
Course Outcomes.CO3: Determining the role of social preferences and strategic settings to decision making
Course Outcomes.CO4: Implementing these theories to experimental economics, policy, decisions by firms, and decisions made in financial markets
